snippet.textDisplay: Ahhh Friday nights, I love you. They're even better with this theme playing. Yakuza might be the one franchise I most want and need to play, I already know it would become a favorite. Would this game be a good starting point (since it says Zero), or should I just play through them chronologically?

snippet.textDisplay: You play any more of these yet?

snippet.textDisplay: If you want to start the series chronologically then 0 is a great choice. But if you really want to get to know these characters and what they grew into, I'd recommend Kiwami first. It's a remake of the first game.
snippet.textOriginal: If you want to start the series chronologically then 0 is a great choice. But if you really want to get to know these characters and what they grew into, I'd recommend Kiwami first. It's a remake of the first game.

snippet.textDisplay: 0 is the best game in the series. Play it now!

snippet.textDisplay: SupraDarky This is my first experience with Yakuza and it is EXCELLENT. I can't recommend it enough. Although you do have to put up with some unfortunately sexist plot lines, it's 100% worth your time.
snippet.textOriginal: SupraDarky This is my first experience with Yakuza and it is EXCELLENT. I can't recommend it enough. Although you do have to put up with some unfortunately sexist plot lines, it's 100% worth your time.

snippet.textDisplay: kiwami is a remake of 1 so you'd be getting about the same experience story wise. 1 on the ps2 only has a (somewhat terrible, but amazing for comedic value) dub which could honestly be worth experiencing all on it's own. 1 is also the most clunky in the series, with the combat being ridiculously stiff and hard to control. You might as well just play kiwami and if possible, get yakuza 2 for the ps2 after that because it's the best in the series (in my opinion)
snippet.textOriginal: kiwami is a remake of 1 so you'd be getting about the same experience story wise. 1 on the ps2 only has a (somewhat terrible, but amazing for comedic value) dub which could honestly be worth experiencing all on it's own. 1 is also the most clunky in the series, with the combat being ridiculously stiff and hard to control. You might as well just play kiwami and if possible, get yakuza 2 for the ps2 after that because it's the best in the series (in my opinion)

snippet.textDisplay: Bubberducky I said that as someone who started with 0 and loved it. I liked it so much that I seemed the older entries to play theme all in chronological order. Is it worth it to play 1 before Kiwami or not?
snippet.textOriginal: Bubberducky I said that as someone who started with 0 and loved it. I liked it so much that I seemed the older entries to play theme all in chronological order. Is it worth it to play 1 before Kiwami or not?

snippet.textDisplay:
0 may be a prequel to the whole series, but it's littered with references and nods to later entries in the series, and playing it first could possibly hamper your enjoyment of the later entries. Also, as someone else said, 0 is one of the most recent games in the series, and either it or kiwami are arguably the most refined games gameplay wise. This, of course, means that playing hte later numbered entries in the series requires going from this heavily refined gameplay back to the unrefined, more clunky gameplay of previous entries.

In an ideal world, I'd recommend starting at yakuza 1 (the original) and working your way through in release order, but that is a lot of games to get through, so I'd instead recommend 4 to start, since they include recaps of the previous games.
snippet.textOriginal:
0 may be a prequel to the whole series, but it's littered with references and nods to later entries in the series, and playing it first could possibly hamper your enjoyment of the later entries. Also, as someone else said, 0 is one of the most recent games in the series, and either it or kiwami are arguably the most refined games gameplay wise. This, of course, means that playing hte later numbered entries in the series requires going from this heavily refined gameplay back to the unrefined, more clunky gameplay of previous entries.

In an ideal world, I'd recommend starting at yakuza 1 (the original) and working your way through in release order, but that is a lot of games to get through, so I'd instead recommend 4 to start, since they include recaps of the previous games.

snippet.textDisplay: Id argue no, the thing is 0 is going to really ruin the constant improvements the series gets throughout its run because you already started when the game perfected 10 years worth of upgrades.
